repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Land Management and Policy
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Land Management and
            Policy Development Project for Indonesia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank Performance was moderately
            satisfactory; and borrower's performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: general
            lessons. The contentious nature of land sector reforms. In
            any country, bringing about reforms to the land sector is
            always contentious and highly political. As such, policy and
            institutional reforms are extraordinarily challenging and
            invariably take a long time to achieve. Lack of high level
            oversight and coordination. High level engagement and
            oversight is required throughout the period of project
            implementation to ensure the policy and institutional reform
            agendas are progressed, and to also re-calibrate the project
            implementation schedule and priorities as is deemed
            necessary due to delays and unexpected challenges
            encountered. Special lessons for land administration in
            Indonesia. Alignment of Project implementation plan with the
            Government's budget cycle. Project Baseline and Project
            Development Objective (PDO) Indicators. The results
            framework and the Monitoring and Evaluation (M and E) system
            go hand in hand and should be designed with implementation
            in mind. Land policy reform. Need for full-time project
            staff. The borrower's ICR report makes a strong case
            for full-time project staff to be assigned both at the
            central and provincial levels. The effectiveness of having a
            long list of legal covenants to mitigate project
            implementation risks.

repnme.cdata!:
Land policy : securing rights to reduce
            poverty and promote rural growth

abstracts.cdata!:
Modern, efficient, and transparent land
            administration systems are important in reducing poverty,
            and promoting growth and sustainable development. Security
            of property rights is central to preserving livelihoods,
            maintaining social stability, and increasing incentives for
            investment and for sustainable, productive land use. Making
            land rights transferable allows the landless to access land
            through sales and rental markets or through public
            transfers, and further increases investment incentives.
            Since the late 1960s, the World Bank has provided financing,
            technical help, and training to strengthen national land
            administration laws, policies, and investment programs.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Land administration policy - To
            promote rural growth and reduce poverty

abstracts.cdata!:
This report on Land Policy, Securing the
            rights to reduce poverty and promote rural growth points out
            that modern systems of efficient and transparent land
            administration are important to reduce poverty and promote
            growth and sustainable development. It is essential to
            ensure the property rights to protect livelihoods, maintain
            social stability and increasing incentives for investment
            and for sustainable use and productive land. The report adds
            that since the late 60's, the World Bank provides
            financing, technical assistance and training to strengthen
            legislation, investment policies and programs on national
            land administration.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Land Management and Policy
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall goal of the Land Management
            Project and Policy Development Project for Indonesia is to
            contribute to government programs in achieving poverty
            reduction, economic growth and promote full utilization of
            land resources in a sustainable manner. The proposed
            objectives of the project are: (i) improve land tenure
            security and enhance the efficiency, transparency, and
            improve service delivery of  land titling and registration;
            and (ii) enhance local government capacity to undertake land
            management functions with great efficiency and transparency.
            There are five project components which achieve the
            objectives by: (a) development of  land policies and related
            laws and regulations to bring coherence and consistency of
            laws and regulations related to administration and
            management of  land affairs; (b) institutional development
            and support to the central and local institutions
            responsible for land administration and management with a
            focus on improving service delivery of  land offices through
            establishment and monitoring of  minimum service standards;
            (c) accelerating and expanding the systematic land titling
            program and developing a Land Information System (LIS); and
            (d) review the experience of  local government management of
            land affairs, provision of  training and capacity building
            to all local governments in standard operating procedures,
            and support to selected local governments (around 5) to be
            models of  how local governments can efficiently and
            effectively undertake their new functions on land affairs.
